## 📅 Course Schedule

Welcome to Introduction to Digital Humanities! We will cover several key topics in digital humanities and R programming. [Each topic will be covered in theoretical/conceptual lectures, followed by practical sessions.]{.highlight-blue} 

Here's a breakdown of our semester:


| Week | Date | Content |
|------|------|---------|
| 1 | 9.9 | <span class="highlight-yellow">Orientation: Introduction to Digital Humanities</span> |
| 2-4 | 9.16, 9.23, 9.30 | <span class="highlight-green">R Programming Basics</span> |
| 5-7 | 10.7, 10.14, 10.21 | <span class="highlight-blue">Quantitative Text Analysis</span> |
| 8-10 | 10.28, 11.4, 11.11 | <span class="highlight-pink">Topic Modelling</span> |
| 11-12 | 11.18, 11.25 | <span class="highlight-orange">Sentiment Analysis</span> |
| 13-14 | 12.2, 12.9 | <span class="highlight-green">Social Network Analysis</span> |
| 15 | 12.16 | <span class="highlight-yellow">Ethics, AI and Future of Digital Humanities</span> |
| 16-17 | Exam Weeks | Final Assessment |

::: {.callout-note icon="false"}
## 🎯 Term Project 
Students are required to review class materials on a regular basis and pick their topic for the term project by week 12.
:::

## 📊 Assessment

Your final grade will be composed of the following elements:

1. **Monthly Quiz** 📝: <span class="highlight-blue">40%</span>
   - Regular assessments to check your understanding of the course material.

2. **Class Participation and Attendance** 🙋‍♀️: <span class="highlight-green">20%</span>
   - Your active involvement in class discussions and activities is crucial!
   
   ::: {.callout-note}
   ## Important
   - Absence of one-third of class time, excused or unexcused, will disqualify you from earning credits for the course.
   :::

3. **Term Paper** 📄: <span class="highlight-orange">40%</span>
   - A digital humanities project of your choice! More details about this will be released around mid term. 


## 🚀 Ground Rules

:::{.callout-note icon="false"}
# 🫡 Ground Rules
Please adhere to these core principles throughout the course:
:::

### Be Open-Minded {.unnumbered}

- Approach new concepts and methods without preconceptions.
- Set aside any stereotypes or misconceptions about digital technologies in humanities.
- Remain receptive to diverse perspectives and unconventional ideas.

### Embrace Frustration as Progress {.unnumbered}

- Understand that frustration is a normal part of the learning process.
- View challenges as opportunities for growth rather than obstacles.
- Give yourself time to work through difficult concepts or technical issues.

### Own Your Learning {.unnumbered}

- Take responsibility for your learning in this course.
- Actively seek out resources and ask questions when you need help.
- Set personal learning goals and work consistently towards achieving them.

### Don't Fool Yourself {.unnumbered}

- Be honest about your understanding and progress.
- Acknowledge your limitations and areas for improvement.
- Critically examine your assumptions and conclusions.

:::{.callout-note}
## Remember
By following these principles, you'll create a positive learning experience for yourself and contribute to a supportive classroom environment for everyone.
:::
